item.title: View From Abroad: Africa’s Economy Is Rising. Now What Happens to Its Food?
item.description: A continent that has long struggled economically is at last poised to make real progress, but it now faces crucial questions, many involving food.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID LEONHARDT
item.media:description: Rice farming in eastern Rwanda last year. Africa’s farmers are vastly less productive than farmers elsewhere, which needs to change in order for the continent to catch up economically.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Yorker Writer Is Surprised by Byline in Chinese Newspaper: His Own
item.description: Peter Hessler, who is also the author of books about China, disavowed an article that appeared with his byline in China Daily, a state-run newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By JESS YU

item.title: News Analysis: Boehner Invites Another Response to State of Union, From Israel’s Premier
item.description: A day after the president’s address, Mr. Boehner invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address a joint meeting of Congress next month for what would effectively be a rebuttal.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: “I don’t believe I’m poking anyone in the eye,” Speaker John A. Boehner told reporters on Wednesday after announcing his invitation to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: Topless Photos Return at The Sun Tabloid’s Page 3
item.description: Its front page, posted online along with a preview of the topless woman, corrected other outlets’ reports that the paper was ending the feature.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: U.S. and Cuba Set to Discuss Diplomatic Ties
item.description: The nations on Wednesday discussed migration, and a meeting on Thursday will cover matters like reopening embassies.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Argentine Phone Calls Detail Efforts to Shield Iran
item.description: The intercepted telephone conversations, if proved accurate, describe an elaborate effort to reward Argentina for shipping food to Iran and for seeking to derail the investigation into a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT and SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: A picture of the prosecutor Alberto Nisman at a rally in Buenos Aires on Wednesday. Mr. Nisman, who was investigating a 1994 attack on a Jewish center, was found dead on Sunday.

item.title: News Analysis: Boehner Invites Another Response to State of Union, From Israel’s Premier
item.description: A day after the president’s address, Mr. Boehner invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address a joint meeting of Congress next month for what would effectively be a rebuttal.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: “I don’t believe I’m poking anyone in the eye,” Speaker John A. Boehner told reporters on Wednesday after announcing his invitation to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: ‘The Red Sari,’ on Sonia Gandhi, Is Released in India
item.description: The book that spans Mrs. Gandhi’s life — from her birth in a small town to her ascent as the Congress Party matriarch — was released without fanfare in India.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sonia Gandhi with her son, Rahul Gandhi, as Mr. Gandhi arrived to file his candidacy for an election in 2014. Last week in India, a book about Mrs. Gandhi was released, five years after its author declined to have it published because of a political uproar.

item.title: France Vows Forceful Measures Against Terrorism
item.description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France announced new security measures Wednesday in Paris, including proposals to add about 2,500 new jobs to fight terrorism and monitor potential threats.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France announced new security measures Wednesday in Paris, including proposals to add about 2,500 new jobs to fight terrorism and monitor potential threats.

item.title: World Briefing: Cameroon: German Hostage Is Freed
item.description: Looking haggard and with a long beard, the former hostage, Robert Nitsch Eberhard, arrived Wednesday in Yaounde, Cameroon’s capital, on a military flight.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Looted Antiquities Are Recovered
item.description: The authorities have unveiled what they said was a record haul of rare antiquities illegally looted from Italy.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: 2 Officers Sentenced in Death
item.description: The police officers were sentenced Wednesday to 10 years in prison for their role in the fatal beating of a university student.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing: Vatican: Pope Revisits ‘Rabbits’ Remark
item.description: Pope Francis sought Wednesday to clarify his remark this week that Catholics should not breed “like rabbits."
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: News Analysis: At Risk of Fragmenting, Yemen Poses Dangers to U.S.
item.description: The chaos could provide greater opportunities both for Iran and Al Qaeda, whose Yemeni branch claimed responsibility for one of the terrorist attacks in Paris this month.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: Houthi militiamen on a road outside the presidential palace in Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: Yemen at Risk of Fragmenting, Posing Challenge for U.S.
item.description: The chaos could provide greater opportunities both for Iran and Al Qaeda, whose Yemeni branch claimed responsibility for one of the terrorist attacks in Paris this month
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: Houthi militiamen on a road outside the presidential palace in Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: Barcelona Journal: Disinherited Daughters Battle Their Father’s City Over Missing Artworks
item.description: Barcelona officials claim the daughters of an industrialist who bequeathed his mansion to his native city covertly removed much of their father’s art collection from the property.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julio Muñoz Ramonet left his mansion to the city of Barcelona. But the city said that as many as 658 artworks were missing, and accused the industrialist’s daughters.

item.title: North Korean Leader May Visit Moscow, Russia Says
item.description: The possible visit would be Kim Jong-un’s first trip abroad since taking control of his country in late 2011, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Russia Presses Ahead With Plan for Gas Pipeline to Turkey
item.description: In the face of European Union opposition to the South Stream pipeline project, Gazprom is moving to an alternate route.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Belgium Offers Partial IDs of 2 Killed in Police Raid
item.description: The federal prosecutor’s office gave only first names for the two men who died in a firefight in Verviers, and said both had Belgian citizenship.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Battle Rages With Rebels at Border Post in Ukraine
item.description: As violence flared in southeastern Ukraine, the president repeated his allegation that thousands of Russian forces had crossed the border to help separatists.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Donetsk on Wednesday. The government said new fighting erupted when Russian troops seized a border checkpoint near Luhansk.
